title: Erdős Problem #404: Prime Power Divisibility of Factorial Sums
description: For which (a, p) is there a bound on k such that p^k divides some sum of factorials starting at a? Let f(a, p) be the supremum. Lin proved f(2, 2) ≤ 254. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #404, from Erdős-Graham [ErGr80], concerns prime power divisibility of factorial sums. Lin (1976) proved the main quantitative result: f(2, 2) ≤ 254. The problem connects p-adic analysis with factorial combinatorics and relates to Problem #403.
overview.problemStatement: For integers a ≥ 1 and primes p, let f(a, p) = sup{k : p^k | a₁! + ··· + aₙ! for some a = a₁ < ··· < aₙ}. For which (a, p) is f(a, p) finite? Secondary: does there exist p and {aᵢ} with v_p(Σ aᵢ!) → ∞? OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines StrictIncSeq, factorialSum, dividesByPrimePower, and f(a, p). The main conjecture (finiteness) and secondary question (unbounded growth) are stated. Lin's bound is axiomatized. p-adic tools (Legendre's formula, asymptotics) and structural lemmas are included. Two concrete examples are proved by native_decide.
keyInsights: f(a, p) measures maximum prime power dividing any factorial sum starting at a
Lin proved f(2, 2) ≤ 254 — the only concrete upper bound known
Legendre's formula: v_p(n!) = Σ⌊n/p^i⌋ ≈ n/(p-1) for large n
Factorial dominance: for a₁ < a₂, the sum is controlled by the ratio a₂!/a₁!
The problem cannot be resolved by finite computation

sections.title: Part 1: Core Definitions
sections.summary: StrictIncSeq structure, factorialSum, dividesByPrimePower, divisiblePowers set, and f(a, p) = sSup of divisible powers.

sections.title: Part 2: Main Questions
sections.summary: secondaryQuestion definition (unbounded v_p of partial sums) and erdos404Conjecture (finiteness of f for all a, p).

sections.title: Part 3: Known Results
sections.summary: lin_bound axiom: f(2, 2) ≤ 254. lin_bound_meaning axiom: 2^255 never divides any such factorial sum.

sections.title: Part 4: p-adic Analysis of Factorials
sections.summary: legendreSum definition, legendre_formula axiom (v_p(n!) = Σ⌊n/p^i⌋), padic_val_factorial_asymp axiom (v_p(n!)/n → 1/(p-1)).

sections.title: Part 5: Structure of Factorial Sums
sections.summary: factorial_sum_mod axiom (a₁! + a₂! ≡ a₁! mod a₂!) and factorial_sum_factored axiom (a₁! + a₂! = a₁!(1 + a₂!/a₁!)).

sections.title: Part 6: Examples
sections.summary: Two proved examples by native_decide: 2^3 | 2! + 3! (so f(2,2) ≥ 3) and 3 | 1! + 2!.

sections.title: Part 8: Summary
sections.summary: Proved erdos_404_summary: conjecture equivalence and open status. Problem remains OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #404 remains OPEN. It asks about the finiteness of f(a, p), the supremum of k such that p^k divides some factorial sum starting at a. Lin's bound f(2, 2) ≤ 254 is the main quantitative result.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would illuminate the p-adic structure of factorial sums and how prime power divisibility interacts with factorial growth. Connects to Legendre's formula and p-adic number theory.
openQuestions: Is f(a, p) finite for all a and primes p?
What is the exact value of f(2, 2)?
Can v_p(Σ aᵢ!) → ∞ for some prime p and sequence?
